com.example.chaosruler.msa_manager.abstraction_classes

Class local_SQL_Helper

  • com.example.chaosruler.msa_manager.abstraction_classes.local_SQL_Helper
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    cache_server_commands, local_OPR_table_helper, local_big_table_helper, local_inventory_table_helper, local_projects_table_helper, local_salprojluz_table_helper, local_salprojmng_table_helper, local_salprojtakala_table_helper, local_vendor_table_helper, user_database_helper

    public class local_SQL_Helper

    an abstract representation of what we define as Local table (or database) in SQLite this abstract implentation is semi-implented with all the basic functionality we need from a local database after initating constructor, we must initate init_vector_of_variables

      halndles data initating on the base class level

    • Constructor Detail

      • local_SQL_Helper

        public local_SQL_Helper(android.content.Context context,
                        java.lang.String DATABASE_NAME,
                        android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase.CursorFactory factory,
                        int version,
                        java.lang.String TABLE_NAME)

        halndles data initating on the base class level

        //Missing function name in @sample

        Parameters:
        context - The context that we work with
        DATABASE_NAME - The database name (ends up being DATABASE_NAME.db as file in device)
        factory - should be initated to null
        version - the database version we are working with on the local level, starting from 1 (integers only)
        TABLE_NAME - The table name that we are going to open
        DATABASE_NAME - the Database name we work with, will become DATABASE_NAME.db as a file in Android device
        TABLE_NAME - the table name to open and query
        context - baseContext to work with, must be valid at all stages
        factory - should be initated to null
        version - the database version we are working with on the local level, starting from 1 (integers only)

    • Method Detail

      • init_vector_of_variables

        public void init_vector_of_variables(java.util.Vector<java.lang.String> vector)

        a function to initate parameer vector_of_variables it actually gets the vector and copies it to base classes vector function is responsible for generating the table as well, will log on exception

        Parameters:
        vector - the input vector, as expected for vector_of_variables

      • onCreate

        public void onCreate(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db)

        Function will use all the initated data to try to do "Create Table" sql query

        Parameters:
        db - an instance of the database we are working with
        Throws:

      • onUpgrade

        public void onUpgrade(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                      int oldVersion,
                      int newVersion)

        if we got a newer version in our android device than the installed version of our current database we will delete all entries of our current database, drop it and its scheme and recreate a new one (without the old data)

        Parameters:
        db - an instance of the database to work with
        newVersion - the new version number we are installing now (in integers)
        oldVersion - the old version number that is installed on the device

      • clearDB

        public void clearDB()

        Just deletes all the database enties, keeping the schema

        Throws:

      • createDB

        public void createDB(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                     java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)

        Create Datbase query handler, in an abstract method

        Parameters:
        db - an instance of the database we are going to work with
        variables - a hashmap of the variables we are going to initate in our database in format of key: name of the value, value: the type
        Throws:

      • createDB

        public void createDB(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                     java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables,
                     java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> foregin,
                     java.lang.String extra)

        an extension of the normal createDB function, it also initates foreign keys (extra is for experts, pushed at the end of the create table query)

        Parameters:
        db - an instance of the database to work with
        variables - a hashmap of the variables we are going to initate in our database in format of key: name of the value, value: the type
        foregin - a list of foreign keys with the value name being on the key and the reference in the foreign database on the value
        extra - an extra added string to push at the end of the Create Table statement

      • get_db

        public java.util.Vector<java.util.HashMap> get_db()

        Select * from DB_NAME query, generated to code function works in threadded way, opening a new thread, though this thread is blocked waiting for the results

        Returns:
        All the database in a vector of hashmap, each item in the vector represents row, each item in the inner hashmap represents a column
        Throws:
        - IllegalStateException

      • add_data

        public boolean add_data(java.util.Vector<java.util.HashMap> variables,
                        boolean check_input)

        Inserts LOADS of data to the database

        Parameters:
        variables - the data we want to add, field name will be on the key, field value is on the value, all the rows are seperated in the vector as different elements
        Returns:
        if at least one of the items was successfull

      • remove_from_db

        public boolean remove_from_db(java.lang.String where_clause,
                              java.lang.String[] equal_to)

        Removes an entry from the database that holds true to the arguement where_clause equals (at least one of the equal_to strings)

        Parameters:
        where_clause - the field name to compare to on each row (if that field holds true, it is deleted)
        equal_to - what to compare the field name to (as in, what data it should be equal to)
        Returns:
        if data removed was successfull

      • remove_from_db

        public boolean remove_from_db(java.lang.String[] where_clause,
                              java.lang.String[] equal_to)

        Removes from database with multiple where clauses requirements

        Parameters:
        where_clause - a vector that holds the multiple amounts of fields that we are going to compare by name
        equal_to - the fields value to compare to
        Returns:
        if the data removal was successfull

      • update_data

        public boolean update_data(java.lang.String where_clause,
                           java.lang.String[] equal_to,
                           java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> update_to)

        a function to update a row in the database with data

        Parameters:
        where_clause - which data should I update? field should be targetted by WHERE clause
        equal_to - the data to compare to the targeted the row we should update...
        update_to - what should we update it to, key = value name, value = value data
        Returns:
        if data update was succesfull
        Throws:

      • update_data

        public boolean update_data(java.lang.String[] where_clause,
                           java.lang.String[] equal_to,
                           java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> update_to)

        Similar to the reguler update_data function, only this one gets multiple parameters to find the specified row to update

        Parameters:
        where_clause - which data should I update? field should be targetted by WHERE clause
        equal_to - the data to compare to the targeted the row we should update...
        update_to - what should we update it to, key = value name, value = value data
        Returns:
        if data update was succesfull
        Throws:

      • get_rows

        public java.util.Vector<java.util.HashMap> get_rows(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> map)

        SELECT * FROM TABLE_NAME WHERE XXX query to kotlin code function works with multi threadding but is blocked until results is generated

        Parameters:
        map - filter by which values? key = name, value = data
        Returns:
        a vector that each element represents a row and each hashtable represents all the columns (key = column name, value = data)
        Throws:

      • get_db

        public java.util.Vector<java.util.HashMap> get_db(java.lang.String sort_by_value,
                                                  boolean isAscending)

        a function to get the entire database (with multi threadding yet this thread is blocked until results is generated) only this one will sort the resuls by specified value

        Parameters:
        sort_by_value - what value should we sort by
        isAscending - true=Ascending sort, false=Descending sort
        Returns:
        a vector that each elements represents a row, and each item in the hashtable represents a column
